awd_titl_txt: Particle Theory for High-Energy Collider Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Nikolaos Kidonakis and Marco Guzzi at Kennesaw State University.  

This research project focuses on aspects of theoretical particle physics relevant to the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and future high-energy colliders. By colliding protons at higher energies than have ever been previously explored, physicists expect to learn more about the fundamental particles of matter and their interactions.  Among such fundamental particles, the top quark is the most massive elementary particle that has been discovered, and thus it is a central part of the physics program at the LHC.  Another particle, the so-called "Higgs boson", is involved in the mechanism through which many of the elementary particles gain their masses, and the determination of the properties of the Higgs boson is a high priority.  Likewise, a precise estimate of the structure of the proton is critical in understanding the details of proton-proton collisions.  All of these questions will be investigated by Professors Kidonakis and Guzzi.  In particular, this research will involve state-of-the-art calculations which will improve theoretical predictions for the production of top quarks and the Higgs particle, and which will increase our knowledge of the structure of the proton. The project will thus advance the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of elementary particles and their interactions, and the search for new physics. The results of this research will be widely disseminated through publication in refereed journals and presentations at international conferences and workshops. This project will also have significant broader impacts. It will involve students as well as a postdoctoral researcher in fundamental research, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists in this field. Outreach activities in the wider community will promote knowledge of physics to the public. 

More technically, the goal of the research project is to develop and implement formalisms that can improve theoretical predictions of higher-order QCD corrections for a large number of processes at the LHC and future colliders as well as the determination of parton distribution functions (PDFs) in the proton. Resummations of soft-gluon corrections will be performed for total and differential cross sections for processes involving top quarks, including processes with three-particle final states in single-particle-inclusive kinematics such as top production in association with electroweak and Higgs bosons, and other processes in the Standard Model and in models of new physics. Soft anomalous dimensions will be calculated for various processes to three-loop accuracy. Moreover, these precision calculations will be used together with selected high-precision hadron collider measurements in dedicated global QCD analyses to constrain heavy-flavor PDFs. Heavy-flavor schemes and factorization theorems in hadronic collisions will be studied, and the impact of processes that involve heavy-quark production in association with a vector boson on the determination of heavy-quark PDFs will be explored. All of these calculations are important for precision studies of the top quark and the Higgs boson, for the exploration of electroweak symmetry breaking and the search for new physics at the LHC and future colliders, as well as for deeper knowledge of the content of the proton, which is a dominant source of uncertainty in precision hadron collider physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Professors Nikolaos Kidonakis and Marco Guzzi performed research in theoretical particle physics that is relevant to high-energy colliders, in particular the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. The purpose of the research was to expand our knowledge of the elementary particles in the universe and the fundamental forces at very small distance scales, and to push the boundaries of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the quantum field theory that describes the physics of the strong interactions.

Professor Kidonakis developed theoretical formalisms and methods to make precise predictions for processes involving the production of top quarks, electroweak bosons, and Higgs bosons at the LHC and future colliders. He also advanced our knowledge of fundamental objects in quantum field theory, i.e. the cusp and soft anomalous dimensions, which are essential to the description of these processes.

The top quark is the heaviest known elementary particle and it has many unique properties and the largest coupling to the Higgs boson. Therefore, top-quark production is a central part of the physics program at the LHC. Professor Kidonakis improved theoretical predictions for a variety of processes involving the production of top quarks by performing state-of-the-art calculations that include higher-order corrections from soft-gluon emission. He calculated cross sections for single-top production and top-antitop pair production, for associated production of a top quark with a Z boson or a photon, and for top-antitop pair production in association with a photon or a W boson. He also performed calculations for top and charged-Higgs pair production in models of new physics. 

These theoretical developments and calculations are important for increasing our knowledge about the top quark, the W and Z bosons, and the Higgs boson, as well as for the search for new physics at the LHC. Furthermore, Professor Kidonakis derived an approximate value for the QCD cusp anomalous dimension, which is an essential ingredient for calculations of heavy-quark production, at an unprecedented level of four loops.  

Dr. Guzzi investigated the structure of the proton and studied the impact of new high-precision measurements of top-quark pair production and other processes at the LHC on the parton distribution functions (PDFs) of the proton which encode the dynamics of the proton's building blocks, quarks and gluons. He studied how heavy quarks (HQs) contribute to the proton's structure and developed the theory framework for HQ dynamics in LHC reactions. These contributions advance our current knowledge of the structure of the proton, in particular the gluon distribution, and improve quantum field theory methods to treat HQ dynamics in high-energy collisions.
 
Dr. Guzzi developed new parametrizations to model nonperturbative HQ contributions in the proton. The possibility that the nucleon might have small, but nonzero nonperturbative HQ components was identified soon after the establishment of QCD as the theory of strong interactions. Many attempts are still going on to quantify these effects in an unambiguous way based on QCD. To this end, Dr. Guzzi developed an amended version of the factorization theorem to account for HQ dynamics in proton-proton collisions and applied this framework to the theory prediction for Z-boson production in association with a HQ at the LHC. This is an important process that plays a critical role in constraining HQ dynamics and will shed light on nonperturbative HQ contributions. These theory developments are important for the next generation of PDF analyses which are going to be extended to higher orders in perturbation theory in the near future and will be sensitive to all these effects.
 
In addition, Dr. Guzzi worked on Physics Beyond the Standard Model of elementary particles. He derived new exclusion limits for the mass of extra gauge bosons known as Z's predicted by string-theory models and used high-precision calculations in QCD to study the impact of Z's on forward-backward asymmetries and other distributions at the LHC.
 
The research findings of the project were widely disseminated through numerous publications in refereed journals and through presentations in international conferences and workshops. Numerical results from the project were shared with the LHC experiments, and these numbers were cited and used in a large number of publications by the experimental collaborations.
 

The broader impacts of the project were also significant. Professors Kidonakis and Guzzi involved undergraduate and graduate students as well as a postdoctoral researcher in their research, and thereby provided critical training for junior physicists doing research in this field. Students from Kennesaw State University (KSU) as well as nearby universities did research under their supervision, and they presented conference talks and were coauthors in research publications. The postdoctoral researcher was also trained in new theoretical formalisms and coauthored publications and presentations in international conferences. The research achievements of Professors Kidonakis and Guzzi and the NSF grant funding that they received became the subject of media coverage and increased public knowledge of particle physics at KSU and the surrounding region.
